tarantino's makes me very happy. we always have the same server (shelley, i think?) and she is awesome. know what else is awesome? their fusilli jerry - it comes in a tomato cream sauce with hunks of spicy italian sausage (i suppose that technically this dish is not called 'fusilli jerry,' but it would be much funnier if they named it that). i always get the same thing when i come here because it is so good, but everyone else i come here with always enjoy whatever they order. the salads and appetizers have been fantastic as well. love the atmosphere, love the food... in conclusion, i say YES to tarantino's.

Very reliable neighborhood place. we've been there a dozen times and we've never had a bad meal, or bad service. Very kid friendly (I hope that doesn't scare people away, as the little ones are all gone by 7 pm). The service is always top-notch, and the owner always stops by and asks how your meal is, which is a wonderful touch, showing they appreciate your business.

Went here with a large group of my dad's friends and it was delightful. We got a bunch of appetizers to sample including a couple pizzas and the calamari and they were splendid.  Everyone loved them.  For dinner I had some sort of cream pasta and it was delicious.  The staff was very friendly and accommodating towards our group, we didn't have to wait at all and it was a Friday night.  Everyone left more than satisfied and I would definitely go back again.

My hubby and I went here for dinner on Friday night, it was great. Thanks to all the yelpers that reviewed this place, we got exactly what we were looking for. We had the calamari salad (delish and perfectly grilled) and the caprese salad...so good! Then I had the black (read squid ink) pasta with shrimp and my hub had the corkscrew pasta with sausage-both were good so we picked off each others plates all night. We didn't save room for dessert but the wine list was great. Overall I'd love to return...and our waiter was awesome, super helpful to a couple from SF, suggested places to visit and things to do. Really went above & beyond to make sure we had a great time in Chicago. Can't wait to go back!!

Was so excited to see butternut squash ravioli with sage butter sauce on the menu - my favorite - but was disappointed in Tarantino's version of the dish.  The sauce was soupy and tasted like chicken stock ?? And the creme brule  seemed curdled.  We also had truffle fries (good) several of the salad offerings (good) pizza (ok) linguine (ok) and chocolate crepes (very good!).  Good service and atmosphere but the food could have been better.

Another favorite of mine. I enjoy the pizza and bruschetta to start with and then almost always order the pasta dish with spinach and chicken. I cannot get enough of it so I have yet to try other things. I did try my moms' pork chop and it was delicious, as was the lamb. The profiteroles are really good too. They have outside seating which is nice and the service has always been attentive. I never leave with leftovers.....its one of those places! PS-It would get five stars if it was closer to my house.

This place has been around forever and we live very close by so we used to come here all the time, but got tired of the menu which didn't change much.  We decided it was time to give it another try and were pleasantly surprised.  I particularly would recommend the pasta dishes - we have tried several, and they are all good.  The smoked chicken farfalle, and rotini with sausage and a spicy sauce are both really good. A bit pricey for pasta, but lots of reasonably priced good wine so I think it all balances out.  The atmosphere is really nice too and a great place to sit outside in the summer.

Brought the father in law here for a casual Sunday night dinner. The room was nice and the food was good, but not great. The wine list was good, but not great. The service was friendly, but maybe a little flirty for a night out with my father in law and his daughter. The pork chop was very good and the mashed potatoes were also very good. My carpaccio appetizer was good, but not great. A little salty for my taste. It seems as if this place is a good place to go when everywhere else is booked.

I used to live right down the street from Tarantino's for years, yet had never ventured inside. Not sure if it was my utmost devotion to my favorite Italian (La Scarola) or just coincidence...  Either way, I finally ventured inside last week for a last minute dinner with a friend. I was somewhat surprised by how small it was, it looked bigger to me from the outside. It's just one room with exposed brick, a small bar and nice low lighting. Pictures on the wall provide some history of the area and the family that owns the place.  The menu had lots of familiar favorite staples.... my Beef Carpaccio appetizer was perfect.... good beefy flavor with a generous helping of filet, lots of parmesan and arugula. Mmmm. I had the butternut squash ravioli for my main course... it came topped with toasty pine nuts, roasted butternut squash and a sage butter sauce. Mama Mia it melted in my mouth and was as smooth as...well...buttah! My friend had the pork chop and it was HUGE with a sweet and tart anise sauce.  Everything was timed well and our server Tom was a doll!  The wine list could be pumped up a bit with some more Italian vintages but I know I sound like a broken record with that one. I'm a wine snob... but the first step to recovery is admitting you have a problem ; )   Tarantino's was a pleasant surprise... just don't tell my lover La Scarola I've strayed... a ride on the Italian Guilt Express can be brutal.

I went here on a double date on a Thursday night.  The service was oustanding.  I wasn't that hungry so I ordered an appetizer and a salad.  Both were very good.  The service was fantastic.  It's one of the better al fresco dining experiences in the city that I've had.  The seating is off of a side street and very quiet.  Overall, a very charming experience.

Warm and charming dining room, very nice outdoor area.  Service was excellent as was the food.  We were the last people there and were in no way made to feel like we had overstayed our welcome.  Can't wait to go back.
Good food, nice outdoor seating area.  The food selection is not as vast as other italian places, but everything is good.  Great for a relaxed meal on a nice evening.

Went to Tarantino's last week and was quite disappointed.  The service was incredibly slow, taking 45 mins to receive our entrees -- the excuse was that the additional tables on the patio in summer overloaded the kitchen's capacity.  In my opinion, if the kitchen can't handle the load, why add the tables? I ordered the salmon with portobella mushrooms and spinach.  It was incredibly salty and ultimately a very boring dish.  My boyfriend ordered the cornish hen which was basically a couple boney drumsticks with a few small cubes of polenta.  There simply wasn't enough food to qualify as an entree! When the server finally checked in on us, I politely let her know that I was a bit disappointed (citing the reasons above).  She subequently brought over the manager and I reiterated my feelings.  Like "Sarah B."'s review below, I was surprised that the manager wasn't more interested in fixing the situation - maybe a complimentary dessert or glass of wine?  NADA. In short, Tarantino's is a let down.  With all the good Italian restaurants in Chicago, this one isn't worth going to, despite the great Armitage location and nicely decorated interior space.

Tarantino's is an old reliable favorite for dinner with girlfriends.  The portions are huge...we always leaved stuffed!  They are a little garlic heavy, so be careful if you're on a date :)  I would honestly recommend anything off the menu. If you're going to splurge on dessert, go with the molten chocolate cake.  It is out of this world.
Consistently good food.  The rigatoni is a favorite.  Comfortable decor - nice brick walls.  Prices are high for the quantity, e.g., $17 for a pasta entre.

Nice ambiance with exposed brick and generally easy to get a table.  Menu items can be decent, but in some cases, strange food combinations(parmesan encrusted shrimp on arugula?  Hmmm...) But...cheap in a relationship management sort of way.  This might not be something that you care about, but before I make a place a regular restaurant, they need to convince me that they care about me. I used to work here, maybe 10 years ago.  Moved away, moved back.  I went here last weekend... my friends reintroduced me to the owner who briefly said hi and then went away.  No free dessert, no how are things, no nothing. I had two bites of my entree, then had to leave(maybe food allergy, I don't know?)  But the waiter didn't notice or ask if I was ok, was the food ok, can I comp anything? The martinis are practically served in thimbles and they are definitely keeping their food cost down, which is shrewd, but lighten up a little, people.  So I guess this place isn't bad.  And I wouldn't discourage you from going.  But there are a lot of other places in town that I feel value me more as a customer, and you can find me  there not here.

Great setting in this cozy place. It blends in with the other small Italian places in Chicago, but it is still a very good bang for your buck. The food is quality and reliable, as is the service. Its a great place for those who live in the area and for those who don't, it might not be a bad idea to make a special trip.

We went here on Valentine's Day & were a little underdressed, but no matter because our server was incredibly helpful & fun.  I ordered the Mushroom Risotto & as our server's laughing at the passion with which I'm eating, I announce, "I am in love with this risotto.  Literally.  In love with it."  I now order it delivered about once a week, it's that good.  Truffle sauce, shaved parmesan on top ... ooo la la!  The only trouble we had that night was that the couple seated next to us actually had the cojones to rip on the fact that my boyfriend was dipping his pizza in ranch dressing ... loudly & right next to us.  I'm talking I could've reached over & pulled his tie down & given him a good scare --- that close.  But that's not the restaurant's fault.  I'm a big fan & if I ever move out of the city, I will miss the mushroom risotto terribly. Ed. Note:  I'm knocking it down a notch, but one one notch because the manager, Jim, did a nice job assuaging my rant.  I ordered delivery from here last night because I desperately needed my mushroom risotto.  It must've been the lady on the phone's first week there or something cuz I had to lead her through the process (read: at the end of the call asking her, "Um, do you need my credit card number?").  Fine.  I can dig that.  Ya gotta learn somehow.  Anyways, my food comes, my mouth is watering, I'm looking forward to that yummy mushroomy truffly goodness & it smells like seafood.  What?  I open it up.  It *IS* seafood.  I call the restaurant & explain the situation.  "That's our risotto of the day - it's made with lobster & shrimp & ---" I interrupt him, "Yeah, that's great, but two things: I ordered the mushroom risotto & I'm a vegetarian, so I don't eat seafood."  He told me that they don't offer that as a menu item anymore, just if it's a daily special.  I said that someone should have told me that at the offset or ... at the very least called me when they noticed they were going to be substituting my meal without my permission (& charging me the extra).  He offered to give me a credit next time I ordered or came in, but I said, "I just waited all this time without eating & now I can't even eat the meal I have - I'm two seconds from giving the bums in the alley a gourmet meal.  It's not like I'm calling to complain & then going to gorge on lobster ... I can't even eat this stuff."  He told me that he completely understood & would void out my charge & rip up my bill.  He also told me to ask specifically for him next time I called/came in. With all of the crap customer service I've received lately, it was refreshing to have some know what REAL customer service is.  Thanks Jim.  I *will* be back ... it might only be on mushroom risotto nights, but I will be back.
